title: The Racial Stereotype Behind Attacks on Tim Scott
sub_head: Sen. Tim Scott’s being called “Uncle Tim,” evoking “Uncle Tom,” in reaction to his rebuttal to President Biden’s address to Congress, made me investigate the epithet’s derivation.
body:
Regarding William McGurn’s “Who’s Afraid of Tim Scott?” (Main Street, May 4): Sen. Tim Scott’s being called “Uncle Tim,” evoking “Uncle Tom,” in reaction to his rebuttal to President Biden’s address to Congress, made me question the epithet’s derivation. I had just read Harriet Beecher Stowe’s “Uncle Tom’s Cabin” and couldn’t reconcile the term, implying craven submissiveness, with the character I met in the novel.
As a slave, Tom complies with his master’s commands except where they conflict with his conscience. In two instances, he draws the line. He refuses to whip a slave woman. And he dies at the hands of his master for refusing to tell where two slave women are hiding, attempting to escape.
Why, I wondered, did the name of Stowe’s hero become pejorative?
I googled “Uncle Tom” and learned its connotation emanated from minstrel-show retellings of Stowe’s classic in the years that followed its 1852 release. In other words, her Tom was redefined by actors comfortable with prevailing racist norms.
My response to the vitriolic reaction to Mr. Scott’s speech is: Just a minute. You condemn racism on the one hand but on the other, rankled by a self-assured senator’s being a black Republican, you use an epithet attributed to minstrel-show retellings performed by pro-slavery men in black face. Where is your moral authority to decry racism?
